conclusion: Several identical small steel balls are released from a position on an inclined plane every 0.1 seconds without initial velocity.
A photograph shows some of these balls at different positions on the incline, labeled as A, B, and C.
The distances between A and B, and B and C are given: AB = 15 cm and BC = 20 cm.
The photograph has a 1:1 scale relationship with the actual object.
Balls are released without initial velocity, they start from rest and accelerate down the incline due to gravity.
The time between releases is 0.1 seconds, which means each subsequent ball starts moving 0.1 seconds after the previous one.
Balls A, B, and C are at different positions on the incline.
Assuming the photograph was taken at a certain time after the first ball was released, we can try to relate the positions of the balls to the time they've been moving.
Let's denote: t = time elapsed since the first ball was released (in seconds), t_n = time elapsed since the nth ball was released.

Since balls are released every 0.1 seconds, if the first ball was released at t=0, then: Ball A: released at t=0, so it has been moving for t seconds; Ball B: released at t=0.1 s, so it has been moving for t - 0.1 s; Ball C: released at t=0.2 s, so it has been moving for t - 0.2 s.
Assuming the photograph was taken at time t, we can express the positions of A, B, and C based on their respective times of motion.
For an object starting from rest and accelerating uniformly, the distance covered is given by: s = (1/2) a t^2, where s is the distance, a is the acceleration, t is the time.
Let's denote the acceleration down the incline as a.

premise: Position of Ball A: s_a = (1/2) a t^2; Position of Ball B: s_b = (1/2) a (t - 0.1)^2; Position of Ball C: s_c = (1/2) a (t - 0.2)^2.
conclusion: Given that AB = 15 cm and BC = 20 cm, we can write: s_a - s_b = 15 cm; s_b - s_c = 20 cm.
